comments.body: Where do those magic numbers come from? Can we link to some docs in a comment?

I did not find them in any docs; at the very least, the reference for `CREATE *` does not mention which errors may be emitted.

-942 came from the stackoverflow that included it. But, as I found with materialized view, the second was found by running the test with the wrong number and looking at the matching `ORA-*` error message.

I can include copies of the error messages, if you like. Or just a link to this very comment. I would recommend that approach should this list need to be extended again, rather than diving into the docs again.
Iâ€™m confused, why do you need the row_number here? This seems like youâ€™re inventing a `LIMIT 1` or something like that. What am I missing?

Yes, we are inventing a limit-1-per-contract-ID here. (This is the recommended approach to solving this problem without `DISTINCT`, which won't work because of the clobs, by various sources.) We used to use this prior to #9484, as well.

comments.body: Could you expand on that? I donâ€™t understand what the issue is and how this fixes it.

As a rule Scala is perfectly aware of type equalities in GADTs, i.e. _for all_ arbitrary `F: * -> *`, `F[A] ~ F[B]`. But sometimes it won't _use_ that fact until you give it a nudge. In this code, the "nudge" is the ascription `T[Query0[DBContract[Mark, JsValue, JsValue, Vector[String]]]]`, but this doesn't apply until the _result_ of `queryByCondition`, so letting Scala operate under the fantasy that Int (or SurrogateTpId) is not Mark, until it really must be, is most convenient.

I think they [finally fixed this in Scala 3](https://twitter.com/not_xuwei_k/status/1332751181119184896).
What does this change do? Does it sidestep the length limit by moving the literal out of the path? If so, letâ€™s please add a comment.

I use it as a sort of weaker TODO that shouldn't block anything (i.e. in some respect not finding it with grep is a feature). Is there a better way to express that in a lightweight way?
not sure, I tend to use NOTE and TODO but NOTE mostly for things that are purely informational and shouldnâ€™t be acted upon. Fine to keep XXX as well if you want.

comments.body: Reviewers, please take special care to examine this function.
Can you provide an example of a query that needs this? I think Iâ€™m not quite following which weird restriction weâ€™re trying to work around here.

Every location that uses the function needs it. Function calls of the form `json_query(x, $y)` where `y: String` fail with `ORA-40454: path expression not a literal`. In other words, while paths use string _syntax_, you cannot put anything but a literal string in the SQL.
Let me rephrase, in which case do we get a value that we need to escape? Daml-LF names cannot have `'` in them so record fields or variants are not an option. What can hit this?

Makes sense, what is stopping us from relying on doobieâ€™s escaping, e.g., something like `fr"${escapethis}"`?
Oh I guess that goes via jdbc to do escaping so itâ€™s not a literal to oracle?
Exactly.

comments.body:
We should be a bit more precise here:

1. LedgerString is limited to 255 char, see https://github.com/digital-asset/daml/blob/4d55b58f19b91630aacc0f811fe575eb1d1bd5c1/daml-lf/data/src/main/scala/com/digitalasset/daml/lf/data/IdString.scala#L297-L319. This applies to parties, offsets and contract ids.
2. package ids are sha256s which are limited to 64 hex digits.
3. There is no length limit on module names and entity names. We should probably use `NCLOB` here.

If you want to omit it from this PR, Iâ€™m fine with that but letâ€™s add at least add a TODO in that case.

comments.body: The naming seems a bit unfortunate but I guess we use it as the template id in other places and having two separate types is a bit annoying. Maybe a type parameter for metadata would be useful

Since the index is in a sense "templateId +" with reference to argument data, it seems unfortunate to introduce another field to model a similar idea, when there is no semantic reason.

My perception of this choice is that we can have

1. a name that is occasionally a little inaccurate, but an aid to "intuition", for what it's worth; or
2. a name that reflects the uninterpreted, formal semantics of the field, but offers no "intuitive" aid to the reader.

I think you can guess which choice I generally favor, though I have chosen the other in this case due to the stronger pull of change conservatism. Which do you think is most valuable to us as maintainers of the code?

I donâ€™t care much about the name, what I would like is a type change when going from query index -> template id which points to type parameter and 2 (or two separate types but I donâ€™t think that makes a lot of sense here) because I donâ€™t trust myself to not mess this up if the types donâ€™t enforce it.

But letâ€™s leave it out of this PR for now.
We do have a type change, because `templateId` is type-parameterized. ðŸ˜•
oh perfect, apologies for missing that. In that case, I donâ€™t really care about the name so for now Iâ€™d just keep it.

comments.body: Not really sure what warning we are trying to silence.
Unused parameter `pas`.

is that something WIP?
what do you plan to do with a contract that does not contain `templateId` value? It's type arg is `Unit`.

actually thinking about it... we can look up `templateId` by `contractId`, but why bother if we can fetch it from DB. Just trying to understand what is the use case for this function, don't think it is being used anywhere.

> don't think it is being used anywhere

It's not and won't in this PR; it will be used for #3388.

> what do you plan to do with a contract that does not contain templateId value?

The use of `Unit` here represents the fact that nothing useful can be put in that slot. Logically, the template ID is always the template ID that was passed as the `tpid` argument, but `tpid.type` will stop compiling at some point in the future, so I don't want to give the false impression that any template IDs are being "looked up". The caller can insert the `tpid` afterwards if they want by `copy`, but I suspect that will never be useful in practice.
